title: Old Mortality, Complete
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: [Note: The Castle of Tillietudlem is imaginary; but the ruins of     Craignethan Castle, situated on the Nethan, about three miles from     its junction with the Clyde, have something of the character of the     description in the text].

snippet: But betAveen GlasgOAv past and GlasgOAv present there is probably asgreat a difference of appearance as betAveen the River Clyde as it comesdoAvn through the lonely uplands of Lanark, by its falls at Wallace's Crags,its orchard-vaUey beloAv Tillietudlem (other-vise Craignethan Castle) and thenoble ruins of BothAvell, and the same river as it Aoavs betAveen the cityquay's, and bears the merchandise of Scotland out by the grey rock-portalof Dunbarton and the islanded firth, to all the countries of the Avorld.

title: Recollections of a Visit to Glasgow with the British Archæological Associations, August 27th to September 5th, 1888. With notes
author: Lambert, George
snippet: After lunching at an hotel, the party drove over toHamilton, crossing Bothwell Brig* on the way to theLesmahagow train for Tillietudlem Station, and thencewalked to Craignethan Castle.

title: Recollections of a Visit to Glasgow with the British Archæological Associations, August 27th to September 5th, 1888. With notes
author: Lambert, George
snippet: The members of the British Archæological Associationvisited Bothwell Castle, the old church of Bothwell, andCraignethan Castle, the Tillietudlem of Sir Walter Scott, in" Old Mortality."
